column1: In the United Kingdom's (UK) 2019 general election
column2: 650 Members of Parliament (MPs) were elected to the House of Commons – one for each parliamentary constituency.

column1: The UK Parliament comprises the elected House of Commons
column2: the House of Lords and the Sovereign. The new Parliament first met on 17 December 2019. After the swearing in of members and the election of Speaker
column3: the State Opening of Parliament took place on 19 December 2019.

column1: The Conservative Party gained a majority of seats in the election. The Scottish National Party increased their number of seats and the Social Democratic and Labour Party and the Alliance Party returned to the House of Commons for the first time since their defeats in the 2017 and 2015 general elections respectively. The Labour Party
column2: Liberal Democrats and Democratic Unionists all suffered losses.

column1: For full details of changes during the current Parliament
column2: see Defections and suspensions and By-elections.

column1: 24% of the members elected in the 2019 election were elected for the first time
column2: or were not members of the previous parliament.
